SENT.plain: We observed an increase in cerebral blood flow (CBF) for control of pain but were otherwise normal
Based on that observation, we implanted stimulators for cervical spinal cord stimulation (cSCS) in three patients who had symptomatic cerebral ischemia
Two had severe basivertebral occlusive disease and one had bilateral carotid occlusive disease
In all three cases, cSCS alleviated the symptoms of ischemia
Xenon-CBF studies or single-photon emission computer tomography (SPECT) showed increased CBF in response to cSCS
Although no mechanism clearly responsible for this remarkable therapeutic efficacy can be proposed yet, further clinical trials of cSCS for inoperable cerebral ischemia may be justified
